questions.correct_answer: C. Failure of GUT to return to the body cavity from its physiological herniation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Failure of GUT to return to the body cavity from its physiological herniation Failure of GUT to return to the body cavity from its physiological herniation. Exomphalos(omphalocele) is herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring. The viscera, which may include liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or bladder, are covered by amnion inside and amnion outside. The origin of omphalocele is a failure of the bowel to return to the body cavity from its physiological herniation during the 6th to 10th weeks.

Highyeild:

Exomphalos describes a central abdominal wall defect in which prolapsed viscera are covered in a thin, three-layered membrane (peritoneum, Wharton’s jelly and amnion) in continuity with the umbilical cord. Association: Exomphalos minor (<5 cm, liver not involved) is commonly associated with other anomalies and the defect is easily closed. Chromosomal anomalies: Can occur in 20-50% of cases; the risk of an associated chromosomal anomaly gets higher when the omphalocele is detected earlier in gestation Trisomy 18: considered the most common associated chromosomal anomaly Trisomy 13 Trisomy 21 Turner syndrome Klinefelter syndrome Pallister-Killian syndrome Other Syndromic associations Beckwith - Wiedemann syndrome Pentalogy of Cantrell OEIS complex: O mphalocele, bladder/cloacal exstrophy, imperforate anus, spinal anomalies omphalocele-radial ray (ORR) complex Differential Diagnosis : Physiological GUT herniation: This diagnosis should only be entertained in early pregnancy prior to 11.4 weeks or in gestation with crown rump length less than 55 mm. The physiologic midgut herniation should not exceed 7 mm in diameter Gastroschisis refers to extra-abdominal herniation (evisceration) of fetal or neonatal bowel loops (and occasionally portions or the stomach and or liver) into the amniotic cavity through a para-umbilical anterior abdominal wall defect. Associated anomalies are rare in a gastroschisis (unlike an omphalocele) except for related bowel abnormalities (i.e. intestinal atresia, malrotation or stenosis from vascular compromise). A fetus with a gastroschisis may have intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Management : In exomphalos major the sac can be dressed with a topical antibacterial agent (e.g. manuka honey, silver sulfadiazine), allowing epithelialisation and later closure of the ventral hernia. If an early closure of an exomphalos major is attempted, close observation for an abdominal compartment syndrome is mandated.

Table:

#MANTRA Neonatal abdominal wall defects Gastroschisis Environmental risk factors (young maternal age, drug use) Bowel complications common (atresia, matting, volvulus) Associated anomalies rare Exomphalos Frequent association with aneuploidies and other genetic syndromes (e.g. Beckwith-Wiedemann) Other structural anomalies common (e.g. cardiac malformations) Large defects may contain liver (exomphalos major) and require delayed or staged closure

questions.text: Identify the type of knot in the Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Granny’S knot The granny knot is a binding knot, used to secure a rope or line around an object. Granny knot ( Slip Knot) Two throws of same type made Right side suture over the left and then the again same way right over left is made This is slipping knot, helps to place the knot at exact site from a long distance. But it is not tight and hence we have to secure it with a Square knot at the end. Granny slips- Above, Below, Above and below

Highyeild:

Knotting Techniques : Knot tying is one of the most fundamental techniques in surgery and a poorly constructed knot may jeopardize an otherwise successful surgical procedure General Principles : The knot must be tied firmly, but without strangulating the tissues. The knot must be as small as possible to minimize the amount of foreign material. The knot must be tightened without exerting any tension or pressure on the tissues being ligated , i.e. the knot should be bedded down carefully, only exerting pressure against counter-pressure from the index finger or thumb. The suture material must not be ‘sawed’ as this weakens the thread and cuts through delicate tissue like a cheese wire. The suture material must be laid square during tying ; otherwise, tension during tightening may cause breakage or fracture of the thread. When tying an instrument knot, the thread should only be grasped at the free end , as gripping the thread with the needle holder can damage the material, resulting in breakage or fracture. The standard surgical knot is the reef knot with a third throw for security , although with monofilament sutures six throws are required for security. When added security is required, a surgeon’s knot using a two-throw technique is advisable to prevent slippage . When using a continuous suture technique, an Aberdeen knot may be used for the final knot. When the suture is cut after knotting, the ends should be left about 1–2 mm long to prevent unravelling . This is particularly important when using monofilament material

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option C : Square Knot (Reef Knot) Two throws of opposite type made Right side suture run over the left and then left side suture run over the right. This is a secure knot and gets tightened well. Square reefs tight - Above, Below, Below and Above

questions.text: Uvula vesicae is produced by which prostate lobe?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Median lobe The mucous membrane immediately behind the internal urethral orifice presents a slight elevation, the uvula of urinary bladder, caused by the median lobe of the prostate. It is often enlarged in benign prostatic hypertrophy. Suring BPH - This Uvula vesicae is also enlarged.

Highyeild:

Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia: Occurs in men over 50 years of age; by the age of 60 years, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH It is a common cause of signifcant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men and the most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men >70 years of age Pathology: BPH affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees. BPH typically affects the submucous group of glands in the transitional zone , forming a nodular enlargement. Effects / Consequences : No symptoms, no BOO No symptoms, but urodynamic evidence of BOO LUTS, no evidence of BOO LUTS and BOO Others (acute/chronic retention, haematuria, urinary infection and stone formation) Investigations : Essential investigations Urine analysis by dipstick for blood, leukocyte esterase, glucose and protein Urine culture for infection Serum creatinine Urinary fow rate and residual volume measurement Additional investigations PSA if indicated Pressure–fow studies Treatment : Conservative measures include watchful waiting in conjunction with fuid manipulation (avoid fuid binge and late night intake) and a reduction in caffeinated and alcoholic drinks Drug therapy is with α-blockers or, in men with a large prostate, a 5α-reductase inhibitor, or both; combination therapy has a better outcome in glands bigger than 35 g Interventional measures include transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which remains the gold standard ; consider HOLEP (holmium laser enucleation of the prostate), open/ robotic simple prostatectomy for large glands; new minimally invasive treatment options that are available to patients include prostate artery embolisation (PAE), water vapor prostate treatment, prostatic urethral lift (Urolift), and water jet treatment (Aquablation)

questions.text: Identify the triangle in the Image below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastrinoma triangle The gastrinoma triangle, also known as Passaro’s triangle. The triangle is formed by joining the following three points: Superiorly: Confluence of the cystic and common bile ducts Inferiorly: Junction of the second and third portions of the duodenum Medially: Junction of the neck and body of the pancreas GASTRINOMA: Most Common functioning malignant pancreatic endocrine tumor (Insulinoma: MC benign) A/w Zollinger Ellison syndrome Site : duodenum Presentation: peptic ulcer ,refractory diarrhea (d/t inactivation of enzyme) Diagnosis Fasting serum gastrin more than 100pg/ml BAO >15 mEq/h Secretin stimulation test Localization - Octreotide scan (SRS) is the pre-operative study of choice for gastrinoma Gastrinomas most commonly arise in 1st part of duodenum within Passaro’s triangle. Those which arise out of this triangle are at increased risk of malignancy.

Highyeild:

Gastrinoma/Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES) Gastrinoma/Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES) is a malignant pancreatic endocrine tumor that functions abnormally. It is more commonly found in men with a mean age of 50 years . It occurs in two forms: sporadic (75%) and MEN-1 association (25%). Those associated with MEN-1 are almost always multiple, early onset, and more common in the duodenum. The most common site of Gastrinoma is the duodenum (50-70%) followed by the pancreas (20-40%). In the duodenum, the most common site is the first part, followed by the second and third parts. Gastrinoma causes increased gastrin secretion, leading to marked gastric acid hypersecretion, which can cause peptic ulcers. All gastrinomas also produce chromogranin A . The most common presenting symptoms are abdominal pain, diarrhea, and GERD . Diarrhea is caused by the inability of the intestinal tract to absorb the large volumes of fluid secreted by the stomach, acid-induced injury to the mucosa of the upper small intestine, precipitation of bile salts, and inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH. The diagnosis of ZES is confirmed by hypergastrinemia with increased secretion of gastric acid . Elevated serum gastrin levels alone are not sufficient to diagnose ZES; basal gastric acid hypersecretion must be demonstrated. A fasting serum gastrin level >100 pg/mL and levels >1000 pg/mL are diagnostic. Elevated serum gastrin level with a pH <2 in the gastric aspirate is almost diagnostic of ZES. Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) is the imaging test of choice for localizing both primary and metastatic gastrinomas. Acid secretion is controlled by PPIs, and pharmacologic control of acid secretion with PPIs has rendered total gastrectomy and other surgical acid-reducing procedures unnecessary. The best predictor of survival for patients with gastrinoma is the presence of liver metastases . LN metastases are not predictive. Resection of all gross disease and metastases may provide palliation of symptoms and may prolong survival. Distal pancreatectomy is recommended for gastrinoma involving the body or tail of the pancreas, while pancreaticoduodenectomy is recommended for gastrinoma involving the head of the pancreas. In MEN-1 , hyperparathyroidism should be treated first because it can complicate the management of gastrinoma. Neck exploration should be performed before the resection of gastrinoma.

Extraedge:

The provocative tests, such as the secretin stimulation test, calcium stimulation test, secretin-plus-calcium stimulation test, bombesin test, and protein meal test , are highly useful if the diagnosis is in doubt. The secretin provocation test is the best. An increase of >200 pg/mL in the gastrin value after administration of secretin is diagnostic. A unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it can be halted by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions. Most patients have peptic ulcers (duodenal ulcers are the most common). ZES must be excluded in all patients with intractable peptic ulcers, severe esophagitis, or persistent secretory diarrhea.

questions.text: Dohlman’s procedure for:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zenker’s diverticulum The treatment of pharyngeal pouches ( Zenker’s Diverticulum ) may be by either open surgical or endoscopic techniques. The endoscopic Dohlman’s procedure is an ideal technique in the elderly. Zenker's diverticulum: Pulsion diverticulum through inferior constrictor muscle in Kilian's triangle Pseudo diverticula Mouth is midline, projects laterally Old age Regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis Treatment in Zenker's diverticula Cricopharyngeal Myotomy Diverticulopexy Diverticulo - Esophagostomy/Dohlman

Highyeild:

Zenker's diverticulum Zenker’s diverticulum is a mucosal outpouching that occurs in the triangular bare area between the upper oblique and lower horizontal fibers of the inferior constrictor muscle due to increased intraluminal pressure. It is a pseudodiverticula that arises posteriorly in the midline of the neck and usually projects left laterally. The main symptom is dysphagia , with undigested food regurgitating into the mouth, swelling of the neck, gurgling noise after eating, halitosis, and a sour metallic taste in the mouth. It is usually seen in patients over 50 years and is associated with cervical webs in 50% of patients. Diagnosis is through a barium swallow , and complications include pneumonia and lung abscess due to aspiration, perforation, bleeding, and carcinoma. The treatment of choice is surgical therapy, which can include cricopharyngeal myotomy, myotomy with excision of the sac, diverticulopexy, or diverticulo-esophagostomy using a linear cutting staple gun ( also known as the Dohlman procedure). Other options: Option A: Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly of the small intestine, and the treatment depends on the presence of symptoms or complications. Surgical removal (resection) of the diverticulum is recommended in cases of symptomatic or complicated Meckel's diverticulum. Option C: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory disorder that affects the muscles and skin. The treatment involves the use of immunosuppressive medications and corticosteroids to control inflammation and improve muscle strength. Option D: Menetrier's disease is a rare disorder characterized by the thickening of the stomach lining and the formation of large folds (rugae). Treatment involves the use of medications to decrease stomach acid secretion and promote healing of the stomach lining. Surgical resection may be considered in severe cases or when complications arise, such as bleeding or obstruction.

questions.text: Cushing ulcer is seen in case of:
questions.correct_answer: B. Stress ulcer in Head injury
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stress ulcer in Head injury Cushing ulcers are associated with a brain tumor or head injury and typically are single, deep ulcers that are prone to perforation. Curling ulcer: Ulcer in duodenum> Stomach in bums Cameron ulcer: Ulcer in proximal stomach in hiatus hernia (vertical ulcers also known as riding ulcers).

Highyeild:

Cushing ulcers, also known as Cushing syndrome ulcers , are a type of peptic ulcer and also a stress ulcer. Cushing ulcers occur in response to extreme physiological stress. They are commonly associated with severe head injuries and other forms of intracranial pathology. Severe head injuries can cause an increase in intracranial pressure due to bleeding, edema, or inflammation. Increased intracranial pressure can lead to alterations in blood supply to the stomach. These alterations result in a decrease in gastric mucus production and an increase in stomach acid secretion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Stress ulcer in Burns: Severe burns can lead to stress ulcers due to disruption in gastric mucosal protection mechanisms. Option C. Ulcer in Hiatus hernia: Hiatus hernia can cause acid reflux and esophageal ulcers, but it is not directly associated with stomach ulcers. Option D . Ulcer in Crohn's Disease: Crohn's disease primarily causes ulcers in the intestines, not the stomach.

Extraedge:

The changes in gastric secretions can lead to the development of stress ulcers, including Cushing ulcers. Cushing ulcers can also occur in other situations of extreme physiological stress, such as severe burns, major surgeries, sepsis, or trauma. However, Cushing ulcers specifically refer to stress ulcers that develop in association with head injuries.

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyperplastic change in the lining mucosa of esophagus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperplastic change in the lining mucosa of esophagus Barrett's Esophagus Distal squamous mucosa converts into columnar epithelium. Occurs due to GERD Predisposes to esophageal adenocarcinoma Stains positive for goblet cells mucin Barrett's Esophagus is a metaplasia of Squamous Epithelium to Columnar Epithelium. Intestinal Goblet cells on Histology is classical finding. GERD is a predisposing factor and they will be usually asymptomatic and detected on endoscopy. Strictures can occur in Barrett's and are always seen in Squamo columnar Junction Incidence of Cancer is 0.5% per patient per year.

Highyeild:

Algorithm for managing Barrett's oesophagus, including dysplasia. Summary of guidelines from the American College of Gastro- enterology (orange) and the British Society of Gastroenterology (blue). BO, Barrett's oesophagus; HGD, high-grade dysplasia; LGD, low-grade dysplasia; MDT, multidisciplinary team; OAC, oesophageal adenocarcinoma; OGD, oesophagogastroduodenoscopy Barrett's Esophagus is a condition where chronic injury to the distal squamous mucosa causes it to be replaced by metaplastic specialized epithelium. This condition is also known as columnar lined esophagus and is most commonly of the intestinal type. The main cause of Barrett's Esophagus is chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) . Symptoms include a long history of heartburn and other reflux symptoms, which are usually more severe and frequent than those experienced by most reflux patients. Barrett's Esophagus is a significant risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma. Diagnosis involves an endoscopic examination with random biopsies, and both an endoscopically visible segment of columnar lining and intestinal metaplasia showing goblet cells on biopsy are required.

Extraedge:

During endoscopy, a red velvety GI type mucosa may be observed between the pale squamous mucosa of the lower esophagus and the lush pink gastric mucosa. Goblet cells in the lining may contain acid mucin, typically sialomucin, and columnar cells contain neutral mucins that are PAS positive. Treatment for Barrett's Esophagus involves antireflux therapy, and surveillance endoscopy is necessary to detect dysplasia or early adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Most Common indication for liver transplant in Pediatric Patients:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biliary atresia Indications for liver transplantation in infants and children include acute liver failure (ALF), chronic liver failure with pruritus, complications of cholestasis and failure to thrive. In young children, the most common liver disease leading to transplantation is biliary atresia MC indication for Liver transplant in Children - Biliary atresia MC indication for Liver transplant in Adults - HCV induced cirrhosis. MC metabolic indication for Liver transplant - Alpha 1 AT deficiency

Highyeild:

Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplant in pediatric patients. It is a rare condition in which the bile ducts inside or outside the liver are blocked or absent , leading to the obstruction of bile flow. If left untreated, it can result in progressive liver damage and cirrhosis. Liver transplantation is the recommended treatment for biliary atresia when other interventions, such as Kasai procedure (a surgical procedure to bypass the blocked bile ducts), are not successful in restoring normal bile flow. Transplantation provides the child with a new liver and is the most effective treatment option for improving long-term survival and quality of life.

questions.correct_answer: B. HIV transmission high in surgical needle injury
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HIV transmission high in surgical needle injury If you experienced a needlestick or sharps injury or were exposed to the blood or other body fluid of a patient during the course of your work, immediately follow these steps: Wash needlesticks and cuts with soap and water. Flush splashes to the nose, mouth, or skin with water. Irrigate eyes with clean water, saline, or sterile irrigants. Report the incident to your supervisor. Immediately seek medical treatment.

Highyeild:

Seroconversion: The rate of HBV transmission to susceptible health care workers ranges from 6% to 30% after a single needlestick exposure to an HBV-infected patient. However, such exposures are a risk only for health care workers who are not immune to HBV. Prospective studies of health care workers exposed to HCV through a needlestick or other percutaneous injury have found that the incidence of anti-HCV seroconversion (indicating infection) averages 1.8% (range, 0% to 7%) per injury HIV: To estimate the rate of HIV transmission, data were combined from more than 20 worldwide prospective studies of health care workers exposed to HIV-infected blood through a percutaneous injury. In all, 21 infections followed 6,498 exposures for an average transmission rate of 0.3% per Needlestick Injuries Prophylaxis : Although exposure to HBV poses a high risk for infection, administration of pre-exposure vaccination or post-exposure prophylaxis to workers can dramatically reduce this risk. Such is not the case with HCV and HIV. Preventing the needlestick injury is the best approach to preventing these diseases in health care workers, and it is an important part of any bloodborne pathogen prevention program in the work place.

questions.text: Maintenance level of Mixed Venous Oxygen Saturation in shock must be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50-70% This is a measure of oxygen returning to the heart from the body after delivery and extraction by tissues. Normal Value - 50-70% In cardiogenic shock and Hypovolemic shock, the tissues takes up more oxygen and hence value is low < 50% In Septic and Distributive shock, the tissues takes up less oxygen and hence more oxygenated blood returns to heart and hence value is high> 70%

Highyeild:

Mixed venous oxygen saturation The percentage saturation of oxygen returning to the heart from the body is a measure of the oxygen delivery and extraction by the tissues. Accurate measurement is via analysis of blood drawn from a long central line placed in the right atrium. (AR)Estimations can be made from blood drawn from lines in the superior vena cava, but these values will be slightly higher than those of a mixed venous sample (as there is relatively more oxygen extraction from the lower half of the body). (SMCQ)Normal mixed venous oxygen saturation levels are 50–70%. Levels below 50% indicate inadequate oxygen delivery and increased oxygen extraction by the cells. Consistent with hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock. Sepsis : High mixed venous saturations (>70%) are seen in sepsis and some other forms of distributive shock. In sepsis, there is disordered utilization of oxygen at the cellular level and arteriovenous shunting of blood at the microvascular level. Therefore, less oxygen is presented to the cells, and those cells cannot utilize what little oxygen is presented. Thus, venous blood has a higher oxygen concentration than normal. Patients who are septic should therefore have mixed venous oxygen saturations above 70%; below this level, they are not only in septic shock but also in hypovolaemic or cardiogenic shock. Although the SvO2 level is in the ‘normal’ range, it is low for the septic state, and inadequate oxygen is being supplied to cells that cannot utilize oxygen appropriately. This must be corrected rapidly. Management : Hypovolaemia should be corrected with fluid therapy, and low cardiac output due to myocardial depression or failure should be treated with inotropes (dobutamine) to achieve a mixed venous saturation greater than 70% (normal for the septic state). New methods : ( SMCQ) Muscle tissue oxygen probes Near infrared spectroscopy Sublingual capnometry

questions.text: Nerve injured in Frey’s syndrome is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Auriculotemporal nerve Frey syndrome is caused by injury to auriculotemporal nerve (Branch of Mandibular division of TRIGEMINAL NERVE) ,typically after surgical trauma to the parotid gland. Normal innervations of the parotid gland is by the postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres from the auriculotemporal nerve During healing, auriculotemporal nerve fuses with great auricular nerve. As such, there is aberrant reinnervation of postganglionic parasympathetic neurons to nearby sweat glands and cutaneous blood vessels. Thus while eating, a stimulus intended for salivation, evokes cutaneous hyperesthesia, sweating, and flushing on ipsilateral cheek.

Highyeild:

Frey’s syndrome (gustatory sweating) results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland with inappropriate regeneration of the post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve that aberrantly stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin. The clinical features include sweating and erythema(flushing) over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland as a consequence of autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell or taste of food. The symptoms are clinically demonstrated by a starch iodine test . This involves painting the affected area with iodine , which is allowed to dry before applying dry starch , which turns blue on exposure to iodine in presence of sweat . Sweating is stimulated by salivary stimulation. PREVENTION: There are a number of quite invasive techniques described to prevent Frey’s syndrome following parotidectomy. These include Sternomastoid muscle flap Temporalis fascial flap Insertion of artificial membranes between the skin and the parotid bed. All these methods replace the barrier between the skin & the parotid bed to minimize inappropriate regeneration of autonomic nerve fibres. Management : Antiperspirants, usually containing aluminium chlorohydrate Denervation by tympanic neurectomy The injection of botulinum toxin into the affected skin

options.label: A
options.text: Done in Upper part of Lower Rib to avoid vessel and nerve injury

options.label: B
options.text: Direction of insertion in posterior and superior

options.label: C
options.text: Inserted into the 4th or 5th ICS along the scapular line

options.label: D
options.text: Insertion area must be palpated digitally to confirm the position

questions.correct_answer: C. Inserted into the 4th or 5th ICS along the scapular line
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inserted into the 4th or 5th ICS along the scapular line In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are indicative of a tension pneumothorax, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. Immediate intervention is required to relieve the pressure and restore lung function. The insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD), also known as a chest tube, is the standard treatment for tension pneumothorax. Inserting a Chest Drain Site of Insertion: Triangle of Safety Boundaries: Anterior to mid-axillary line Above level of nipple Below and Lateral to Pectoralis Major This usually gets inserted in 5th ICS level. Steps in ICD Insertion: Meticulous Sterility maintained. Insert Local Anaesthesia up to Pleura. Sharp dissection to Cut only the Skin. Blunt Dissection using Artery Forceps through the muscles - Intercostal and Serratus anterior. Oblique tract is made so that the parietal pleura is tunneled to avoid leakage of air. Drain in cases of Hemothorax and Pneumothorax should aim the Apex Drain for Empyema and Pleural effusion should be at Base Drain should pass at the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to neurovascular bundle. Don't apply any clamp in Drain as it may be forgotten to be removed. Don't apply suction also. Bubbling drain must never be clamped. Check the drain location by a Chest X ray.

Highyeild:

A tension pneumothorax is caused by excessive pressure build up around the lung due to a breach in the lung surface which will admit air into the pleural cavity during inspiration but will not allow any air to escape during expiration. The breach acts as a one-way valve. This leads to lung collapse . The removal of the air is through the surgical incision by inserting an underwater drain in the pleural cavity. This excessive pressure can also prevent the heart from pumping effectively which may lead to shock.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- When it comes to the insertion of an ICD for tension pneumothorax, the following statements are generally true: OPTION A. Done in Upper part of Lower Rib to avoid vessel and nerve injury: The ICD is typically inserted in the upper part of the lower rib to avoid injury to underlying structures such as blood vessels and nerves. OPTION B. Direction of insertion is posterior and superior: The ICD is inserted in a direction that is posterior (towards the back) and superior (upwards) to ensure proper placement in the pleural space. OPTION D. Insertion area must be palpated digitally to confirm the position: Before the insertion of an ICD, the insertion area is usually palpated digitally to confirm the position and identify the correct intercostal space.

Extraedge:

Indications for surgical intervention for pneumothorax include: Second ipsilateral pneumothorax First contralateral pneumothorax Bilateral spontaneous pneumothorax Pneumothorax fails to settle despite chest drainage Spontaneous haemothorax: professions at risk (e.g. pilots, divers) Pregnancy

questions.text: Retrosternal Goiter Approach is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transcervical approach Retrosternal goitre is 99% extension from Goiter in neck due to enlargement. And such extended retrosternal goiters are mostly removed by neck incision itself by putting the fingers and hooking out the gland. Such manoeuvre of removal via neck incision is known as Toboggan Technique. Very rarely Sternotomy is done if the goiter is primary mediastinal goitre.

Highyeild:

A retrosternal goiter refers to an enlarged thyroid gland that extends behind the sternum (breastbone) into the mediastinum (central chest cavity). Surgical treatment may be necessary to remove or manage the goiter. In such cases, the preferred approach is the transcervical approach. The transcervical approach involves accessing the retrosternal goiter through an incision made in the neck, specifically in the cervical region. By approaching the goiter from the front of the neck, can safely and effectively remove the enlarged thyroid gland without the need for a more invasive procedure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- The other options mentioned are not the preferred approaches for retrosternal goiter: OPTION A. Transthoracic 2nd ICS: This approach implies accessing the goiter through the second intercostal space in the chest, which is not the standard approach for retrosternal goiters. OPTION B. Transthoracic 4th ICS: Similarly, accessing the goiter through the fourth intercostal space in the chest is not the usual approach for retrosternal goiters. OPTION C. Transsternal via Anterior mediastinum: This approach involves accessing the goiter through a midline incision in the sternum (breastbone) and going through the anterior mediastinum. While it is a valid approach for some cases of retrosternal goiters, it is not the most common or preferred approach. Therefore, the correct answer is D. Transcervical approach.

Extraedge:

Less invasive than other approaches Involves a neck incision Mobilization of the thyroid gland Use of retractors for optimal exposure Identification and protection of vital structures Allows for complete goiter removal Associated with lower complication rates Faster recovery and shorter hospital stay

questions.text: A 14 week post-natal woman presents with fluctuant breast swelling, what would be the treatment?
questions.correct_answer: D. Repeated Aspirations under antibiotic cover.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Repeated Aspirations under antibiotic cover. The clinical diagnosis of a lactating mother at 14 weeks is usually a mastitis followed by Breast abscess. Abscess presents with Fluctuant swelling During cellulitis stage- only Antibiotic such as Flu cloxacillin and Co amoxiclav can be used. Feeding can be given via the affected stage at this time. Analgesics will help to relieve pain with support of breast. In antibiotics alone used in the presence of underlying pus- Antibioma will form. Olden days- Incision and Drainage was advised if not resolves in 48 hours. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover (if needed under USG Guidance) to be performed. This allows resolution without Incision and Drainage and will also allow breast feeding in the affected breast.

questions.text: What is the swelling shown in the Image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Branchial cyst The swelling' shown in the image is having following features: Anterior Triangle swelling (So pharyngeal pouch ruled out) Not in midline (Hence Dermoid cyst and Pretracheal bursa ruled out) Only swelling which suits the location at upper 1/3rd level of Sternocleidomastoid muscle is Branchial cyst. These are benign, congenital cystic masses that are formed due to an abnormal embryonic development of the branchial apparatus. They are most commonly seen in the lateral neck region and are lined by squamous or respiratory epithelium.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Pharyngeal pouch: Zenker's diverticulum is an example and occurs due to the herniation of the pharyngeal mucosa through the Killian's triangle, a muscular defect in the inferior constrictor muscle. They are typically seen in the elderly population and can present with dysphagia or regurgitation. Option C. Dermoid cyst: These are also congenital cystic masses that contain skin appendages and are typically found in the head and neck region. They can also contain other tissues such as bone, cartilage, and fat. Option D. Pretracheal bursa: This is a small sac that is present anterior to the trachea and can occasionally become inflamed, leading to a pretracheal abscess.
